9 storia capolavoro e gameplay divertente, da giocare

Con BioShock Infinite e i suoi due DLC "Burial at Sea" si chiude - diciamo cos√¨ - la trilogia di BioShock iniziata qualche anno prima. Conviene fare questo gioco dopo aver giocato gli altri due? Questa √® una recensione no-spoiler, ma la risposta curiosamente √® "no". Si pu√≤ giocare a Infinite anche senza aver fatto gli altri due BioShock. Tuttavia √® d'obbligo farli prima di affrontare le due parti di Burial at Sea.
Chi ricorda i primi due capitoli, l'inizio di Infinite d√† una certa sensazione di spaesamento.
Dagli ambienti claustrofobici del primo e a quelli pi√π ampi ma ancora "sigillati" del secondo, si passa ad un'ambientazione completamente ribaltata, con una Columbia che fluttua nel cielo dando quella sensazione di "spazi sconfinati" mai vista nei precedenti capitoli.
Poi, poco a poco, percorrendo le zone, si inizia a riconoscere il marchio di fabbrica che ha contraddistinto BioShock fin dal primo capitolo: nel bene e nel male.
Columbine √® l'esatto opposto di Rapture: lo √® negli spazi aperti, nella gente che ci vive, nei colori, nei nemici. Ma le meccaniche di gioco sono sempre le stesse: un continuo cercare cercare e cercare oggetti ovunque, senza sosta, alla spasmodica ricerca di monete e consumabili, esplorando ampie zone anche slegate dal percorso principale e che puntualmente tornerai a rivisitare pi√π tardi. E lo stesso con i pessimi automatismi del gioco, ovvero si libera un'area dai nemici, si entra in un'altra zona/porta/strada concludendo uno step di una missione, si torna indietro e bummm: nuovi nemici nella stessa zona precedente. Sempre.
I difetti finiscono qui.
I combattimenti con armi e plasmid rimangono anch'essi simili ai precedenti capitoli. I nemici hanno una IA piuttosto elementare: spesso si incastrano negli angoli, corrono poco o scoordinati, si dimenticano quasi subito di noi se ci nascondiamo e hanno in generale comportamenti pi√π da allucinati che da gente normale. Per√≤ combatterli con le "forze della natura" e con una discreta variet√† d'armi √® divertente e regala grandi soddisfazioni.
Le ambientazioni sono meravigliose, i personaggi buoni e cattivi sono caratterizzati alla grande, i dettagli sia scenografici che di sceneggiatura sono ammirevoli.
La trama generale √® incredibilmente complessa, riuscire a starci dietro √® complicato e l'effetto √® amplificato se si sceglie la lingua inglese sottotitolata. Tuttavia il doppiaggio inglese √® sublime, gli effetti sonori veramente d'impatto e le musiche accompagnano i combattimenti donando la giusta dose d'ansia.
I due DLC da una parte chiudono la trama della trilogia, dall'altra riescono ad essere ancor pi√π un ritorno alle origini con ambientazioni claustrofobiche e vecchi personaggi e nemici mai dimenticati.
In sintesi parliamo di un gioco veramente superlativo, non perfetto ma carismatico a non finire. Si passa troppo tempo a cercare, cercare e cercare, con l'ansia di non avere abbastanza "lockpick" per aprire le serrature, di non avere abbastanza bonus per sconfiggere i nemici, di ritrovarsi in aree precedentemente ripulite con un fastidioso "respawn" dei nemici.
Ma che capolavoro scenico, che trama coinvolgente, che personaggi fantastici!
Consigliatissimo, anche a tanti anni di distanza dalla sua uscita.

This game is one of the best video games I have ever played.  That's saying a lot considering I have been playing games since 1999.  The story line, characters, art, gameplay, this game has it all!!  Definetely worth playing!  Even if you have not played any of the other games in the Bioshock series, pick this one up and give it a try, it is not necessary to have any knowledge of the other games in the series, it stands alone.  So glad I decided to give this game a go and I was actually sad when I finally beat it because I didn't want it to end.  I suggest definetly taking your time with it and enjoying the entire atmosphere of all the levels.

I have tried to play through this game 3 times now, and have stopped every single time. I kept insisting to myself that I liked the game but that I am just terrible at finishing games. I am terrible at finishing games but I do not, in fact, like this game. My third and final attempt to play through bioshock infinite came right after a replay of the other two bioshock games. I love bioshock 1 and 2 for their wonderful atmosphere, dense levels that are a joy to explore, and very importantly, very little downtime. 
This brings me to bioshock infinite. The game has larger, less dense and interesting levels, levels that require the addition of sprinting into the game. The atmosphere is less strong. But most unforgivably, the game has constant downtime. Now, by downtime, I mean moments in the game where absolutely nothing interesting is happening. No exploration, no combat, instead you are just walking through a mostly empty level or even worse, listening to Elizabeth drone on and on about uninteresting things.
This brings me to the combat. In bioshock 1 and 2, the choice to engage in combat was one of the most important things you would face. In these games, resources were very limited, so when you encounter something like a big daddy, you have to consider if you have enough ammo and health to do so, and if spending those resources to kill it will be worth the adam that they provide.
Bioshock infinite has absolutely none of these elements. Instead you are positively showered with ammo and healing items, thrown to you every 2 seconds by Elizabeth. There is very little in the way of choosing your battles.
Next is the story. Bioshock 1 and 2 told you the story via radio communication with your allies and you enemies. This is genius game design because it allows the story to be told to you without grinding the gameplay to a painful halt. Bioshock infinite decides to can this element and instead slows the game down to a crawl to force feed you the story. This is not fun.

By far this is my favorite game ever. Got me into the history the whole time. A totally 10/10 gameplay.

Overrated.

That's not to say that it isn't good. I'd argue the story is probably one of the best elements. Atmosphere? Pretty cool, not as good as the previous entries.

In terms of gameplay though? Hmmm... Definitely fun, but not amazing. Very generic and doesn't do anything particularly better than other first person shooters I've played and would definitely prefer. 

So, why am I b*tching? Well, obviously I'm giving this game a good review, it was just mildly disappointing because this game is a victim of it's own hype. People acted like this game was the second coming of Christ when it first came out (and still do, looking at some of the recent reviews), and because of that I had extraordinarily high expectations coming into this game. Which it really didn't quite meet. Still a good game, still worth it on sale, but damn, guys, chill on the hyperbole, this game is an 8/10, maybe a 9/10 at best, but I'd lean towards the former.

Good game, wait for it on sale, play the previous entries first, and even then, don't walk in expecting too much and you may be pleasantly surprised.
Fun gameplay, great replay value. DLC is well worth it and adds a lot to the story, tying it back brilliantly with the first two Bioshock games. I'm happily completing my 4th playthrough as we speak.

Personally, I think Bioshock Infinite is one of the greatest video games ever made. It's an absolute masterpiece. The gunplay is just right, the soundtrack and sound design are brilliant, and the story is amazing and brilliantly voice acted. I wish I could play it for the first time all over again.

Clash In The Clouds is alright; it's fun if you're into survival gamemodes.

Burial at Sea is a great extension of the campaign, set in a pre-downfall Rapture from the first games, and delivers a satisfying ending to the trilogy.
